Award.AwardTitle: Center for Accelerator Science and Education at Stony Brook University
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports advanced accelerator physics research and education program at the existing Stony Brook Center for Accelerator Science and Education (CASE) at Stony Brook University (SBU). It draws on CASEs ability to pursue cutting-edge, forward-looking explorations in accelerator physics to study the physics of advanced cooling for circular high-energy hadron and lepton colliders.

Intellectual Merit:
This research is focused on developing the groundbreaking concept of Enhanced electron Cooling (EeC), a novel stochastic cooling techniques with bandwidth of ~(10)^17 Hz capable of cooling TeV-scale hadron and muon beams. The availability of such cooling technique would have a major impact on the discovery potential of future high-energy colliders.

Broader Impact:
The success of this research will entail transformational advances in various branches of science, affording broad benefits to society. Cooling techniques would significantly impact both nuclear and particle physics through the enhanced capabilities of existing and future colliders. The process of enhanced bunching could bring about a new generation of compact but intense sources of incoherent radiation. Two students and one postdoc involved in the program will be immersed in an atmosphere of cutting-edge accelerator research and development. The group will work towards broadening the educational, outreach, and diversity programs at SBU and CASE.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We established a unique NSF-supported advanced accelerator physics research and education program at Stony Brook University, New York under auspices of Center for Accelerator Science and Education (CASE). The program achieved all of its objectives:

  1. Established regular curriculum and research program to train next generation of scientists and engineers http://case.physics.stonybrook.edu.
  2. Advanced the field of accelerator science by developing Coherent electron Cooling of hadron beam, surpassing any other technique by orders of magnitude, and advanced plasma wakefield accelerator driven by CO2 laser.
  3. Developed a unique program of educational outreach that will provide broad access to research accelerators.

 

We continued expanding the CASE’s advanced accelerator physics research program by involving teaches from BNL and FNAL. We established a regular 2-year teaching cycle which currently includes five graduate-level and one undergraduate-level accelerator physics courses. The CASE accelerator science program involved on average ten-twelve graduate students (both MS and PhD) and two-to-three undergraduate students.

Two faculty members continues leading theoretical, computational and experimental research in advanced hadron cooling techniques and plasma wakefield accelerators. CASE conducted two main experiments: Coherent electron Cooling (CeC) experimental at RHIC facility and Plasma Wakefield (LPWA) driven by high power CO2laser at Accelerator Test Facility (both at BNL). Our experimental activities at SLAC are restarting with FACET II commissioning. Both experiments made significant progress. Significant portion of the NSF funds was used to build and commission a unique CeC system with Plasma-Cascade Amplifier. It resulted in world-first demonstration of the key components of the CeC physics: the ion imprint and its amplification by Plasma-Cascade Amplifier. Similarly, the LWPA at ATF demonstrated first acceleration of electron beam using CO2 laser, as well as first direct imaging of the plasma-bubbles.

The CASE faculty and researchers demonstrated world-record performance of CW SRF photo-emission electron gun, hosted Coherent electron Cooling Theory, Simulation and Experiment workshop, tripped the scope of accelerator science courses offered by CASE.

All CASE graduates finding excellent jobs well before graduation, which is indication of excellent quality if CASE training and education programs. CASE continue attracting excellent graduate and undergraduate students using advertising on CASE website as well by presenting CASE program at second year graduate seminars. CASE faculty supervises in average ten-to-twelve graduate students, with two-to-three per year graduating.  Thesis works of diverse body of CASE graduates is also recognized with a number of important awards: for example, two female graduates, Irian Petrushina and Prachi Chitnis received RHIC and European Physical Society thesis awards.

The CASE outreach program includes presentations in schools, popular lectures to general public and an internship summer program for undergraduate students.
